summary.seg: This 14th century manuscript Repertorium is an alphabetical list of topics treated in the Bible which was used to assist with writing sermons. It begins imperfectly with ‘castitas’ and ends with ‘zona’. There is a gap between S and X. The last folio (fol 130v) contains the Arms of William Bateman (c1298-1355) the Bishop of Norwich who founded Trinity Hall, Cambridge in 1350. This suggests that it was one of the original books bequeathed by him to the College and listed in the Master’s Statute book (THAR/1/6), either the Repertorium Tusculani or the Liber Concordantiarum.

At the end of the manuscript are four parchment pages (fols. 132r – 135v) from the opening of the third book of the Decretals of Pope Gregory IX (1227–1241). It ends imperfectly. The Decretals was commissioned by Pope Gregory IX in 1230. Decretals are papal letters that clarify questions of Canon law. The complete Decretals or the Liber Extra is divided into five books (Iudex, Iudicium, Clerus, Connubia/Sponsalia, and Crimen, that is, Judge, Trial, Cleric, Marriage, and Crime). This third Book of Decretals concerns the laws governing the lives of the clergy, including marriage.

supportDesc.extent: iii modern paper flyleaves + 135 folios (foliated 1 – 131, 1 – 4) + iii modern paper flyleaves

binding.p: 20th century,red native-dyed goatskin over paste boards, white endbands (previous 19th century binding kept with MS); wear and staining on fols. 128, 130, 131 suggest book was originally chained

history.provenance: It has been conjectured that the book is one of those given to the College by William Bateman (c1298-1355), Bishop of Norwich Bateman, William, c1298-1355 as it contains a drawing of his Arms (a crescent ermine with a Maltese cross above) on fol 130v .

recordHist.source: Description draws on James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall

listBibl.bibl: James, M. R. (1907). A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Trinity Hall. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 9-10.

msItem.title: Repertorium
msItem.explicit: 130v universus Deus. vivit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen.

supportDesc.support: Paper. Watermarks; crossbow, with triangle at front, c.f. Briquet 705(fols. 1 – 130); clover-leaf on long stem, c.f. Briquet 6221(fol. 131). Both watermarks very similar to ones identified by Briquet from 14th century France.

layout.seg: 33 – 37 long lines, ruled in ?plummet, catchwords, quire signatures (first part of quire)

decoDesc.decoNote: Brown penwork initials [3 l.] with minor geometric and foliate flourishing.

physDesc.additions: Brown ink drawing (crescent ermine, Maltese cross above, on dark ground) in lower part of fol. 130v

msItem.title: Third Book of Decretals
msItem.incipit: 132r: ut laici secut [Ut laici secus altare, quando sacra mysteria celebrantur, tam ad vigilias quam ad missas penitus stare vel sedere inter clericos non praesumant; sed pars illa, quae cancellis ab altari dividitur, tantum psallentibus pateat clericis].

supportDesc.condition: Manuscript is closely trimmed along top of text. Folio 4 has been torn in half

layout.seg: Two columns of 55 lines, ruled in plummet, running headers.

decoDesc.decoNote: Display script [4 l.] in alternate red with blue pen-flourishing and blue with red pen-flourishing for incipit, fol. 1r; red penwork initials [1 – ca. 3 l.] for text divisions; red penwork linefillers
